caption_original:
Did you know that freshwater turtles have long been found in abundance in Western Quebec? In recent years, habitat destruction and disturbance by human activity has left many species vulnerable, including the Blanding’s Turtle and Map Turtle.

Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with Nature Conservancy of Canada to expand the protection of threatened turtle habitat in the Outaouais valley and l’Isle-aux-Allumettes. http://ow.ly/xD8e302heXG

Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with Nature Conservancy of Canada to eand the protection of threatened turtle habitat in the Outaouais valley and l’Isle-aux-Allumettes.

caption_original: Did you know that wading birds, with their long beaks, necks and legs, are well adapted to fishing? Where can I go to watch them in Canada? At the Lac Saint-François National Wildlife Area in Quebec. Go to the Digue aux Aigrettes sector, take the trail developed and complemented by several lookouts and you may watch them, including the graceful Sandhill Crane or the majestic Great Blue Heron. http://ow.ly/pkra302C5Sb http://ow.ly/SbOM302C5T2

caption_original: Did you know cooling your food, house and car may also be warming the planet? Chemicals called HFCs, used in refrigerators, air conditioners and other places, are powerful greenhouse gasses. That’s why Canada is joining other nations in Vienna to work out an agreement to phase down HFCs under the Montreal Protocol.

caption_original:
July 17 is Lake Superior Day. Did you know that Anishinaabe tell tales of an underwater creature, Mishipeshu or “the Great Lynx”, which lives in Gichi Gami, the “Great Sea” or “Lake Superior”, and can cause great storms? Safe passage across the lake depends on properly placating this creature. 

What’s your Great Lakes story?  Share it on Twitter by using the hashtag #GreatLakesForum. http://ow.ly/nCSL302eRlk

caption_original: Going outside? Temperature is more than what’s on the thermometer! Humidex combines temperature and humidity into one number that reflects the perceived temperature. The humidex range indicates that below 29 means no discomfort, while above 40 means great discomfort and it's best to avoid exertion. http://ow.ly/tgWA302cuwf

caption_original:
Did you know the French word “barachois” means “lagoon separated from the sea by a sand bar”? 

Environment and Climate Change Canada is pleased to work with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect 470 hectares of marshland habitat in the Barachois of Malbaie, a unique freshwater estuary located at the easternmost tip of the Gaspésie Peninsula. These ecologically sensitive lands are a key breeding area for the Yellow Rail and other migratory birds and support many aquatic species including the Atlantic Cod, Striped Bass, American Eel and the Atlantic Salmon. http://ow.ly/RdAj3023N3P
caption_cleaned: Did you know the French word “barachois” means “lagoon separated from the sea by a sand bar”? Environment and Climate Change Canada is pleased to work with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect hectares of marshland habitat in the Barachois of Malbaie, a unique freshwater estuary located at the easternmost tip of the Gaspésie Peninsula. These ecologically sensitive lands are a key breeding area for the Yellow Rail and other migratory birds and support many aquatic species including the Atlantic Cod, Striped Bass, American Eel and the Atlantic Salmon.

caption_original:
Ever heard of geocaching? It’s a techno treasure hunt fun for all ages. As you explore the trails, use a GPS to find the official geocaches hidden along the way and uncover the secrets of plants and animals in an original way. 

The Cap Tourmente and Lac Saint-François National Wildlife Areas in Quebec are two locations where you can practise geocaching. Keep your eyes peeled — Mother Nature has some surprises in store for you! http://ow.ly/TzRS302a2CU
caption_cleaned: Ever heard of geocaching? It’s a techno treasure hunt fun for all ages. As you elore the trails, use a GPS to find the official geocaches hidden along the way and uncover the secrets of plants and animals in an original way. Keep your eyes peeled — Mother Nature has some surprises in store for you! 2CU

caption_original:
Did you know the amount of protected areas in Canada has increased about 70% in the past 20 years?  If you were to combine all of those areas together, they would amount to about the size of Ontario. 

Protected areas are lands and waters where development and use are restricted, so we can conserve Canada's unique landscape, endangered wildlife species and their habitats. http://ow.ly/NRYv302hP8k

caption_original:
Every day, we inhale pollutants that damage our health. In 2014, emissions of five key air pollutants in Canada were 9% to 63% lower than in 1990. Ammonia emissions were 21% higher than in 1990. 

Environment and Climate Change Canada has updated its sustainability indicators with the latest available air pollutant emissions data. Explore the latest indicators or find out about emissions where you live through interactive maps. http://ow.ly/pfay301UCNb
http://ow.ly/ZRo5301UCOp

Elore the latest indicators or find out about emissions where you live through interactive maps.

caption_original:
Birds can sometimes cause damage to property or pose a threat to humans. You can scare migratory birds that are causing or are likely to cause damage, but it is prohibited to kill, wound or capture them. Be careful not to harm them and respect the Migratory Birds Convention Act, 1994. 

For more information, contact Environment and Climate Change Canada's Public Inquiries Centre at 1-800-668-6767 or by e-mail at ec.enviroinfo.ec@canada.ca.

http://www.ec.gc.ca/nature/default.asp?lang=En&n=496E2702-1
http://www.ec.gc.ca/nature/default.asp?lang=En&n=9AAA86EC-1

You can scare migratory birds that are causing or are likely to cause damage, but it is prohibited to kill, wound or capture them. Be careful not to harm them and respect the Migratory Birds Convention Act, . For more information, contact Environment and Climate Change Canada's Public Inquiries Centre at -800-668-6767 or by e-mail at ec.enviroinfo.ec.ca. 1 1

caption_original:
Enjoy safe shellfish - check before you harvest!

 
Bivalve shellfish such as oysters, clams, scallops and cockles feed on microscopic plankton in the water. Changes in water quality can cause bacteria, biotoxins or viruses to build up in the shellfish tissue and can make those who eat it sick. Even cooked shellfish can still contain biotoxins! http://ow.ly/keHN301UDlz

Only harvest shellfish in open areas!
